fields.description:
The machine has 620 MB RAM under Windows 2000 with JDK 1.4.1_01! The scheduler and the hand made backup produce this message. After a restart of the tomcat one backup will be create from JIRA!

catalina.bat of the tomcat: 
rem Execute Java with the applicable properties
if not "%JPDA%" == "" goto doJpda
if not "%SECURITY_POLICY_FILE%" == "" goto doSecurity
%_EXECJAVA% %JAVA_OPTS% -Xms256m -Xmx384m %CATALINA_OPTS% %DEBUG_OPTS% -Djava.endorsed.dirs="%JAVA_ENDORSED_DIRS%" -classpath "%CLASSPATH%" -Dcatalina.base="%CATALINA_BASE%" -Dcatalina.home="%CATALINA_HOME%" -Djava.io.tmpdir="%CATALINA_TMPDIR%" %MAINCLASS% %CMD_LINE_ARGS% %ACTION%
goto end
:doSecurity
%_EXECJAVA% %JAVA_OPTS% -Xms256m -Xmx384m %CATALINA_OPTS% %DEBUG_OPTS% -Djava.endorsed.dirs="%JAVA_ENDORSED_DIRS%" -classpath "%CLASSPATH%" -Djava.security.manager -Djava.security.policy=="%SECURITY_POLICY_FILE%" -Dcatalina.base="%CATALINA_BASE%" -Dcatalina.home="%CATALINA_HOME%" -Djava.io.tmpdir="%CATALINA_TMPDIR%" %MAINCLASS% %CMD_LINE_ARGS% %ACTION%
goto end
:doJpda
if not "%SECURITY_POLICY_FILE%" == "" goto doSecurityJpda
%_EXECJAVA% %JAVA_OPTS% -Xms256m -Xmx384m %CATALINA_OPTS% -Xdebug -Xrunjdwp:transport=%JPDA_TRANSPORT%,address=%JPDA_ADDRESS%,server=y,suspend=n %DEBUG_OPTS% -Djava.endorsed.dirs="%JAVA_ENDORSED_DIRS%" -classpath "%CLASSPATH%" -Dcatalina.base="%CATALINA_BASE%" -Dcatalina.home="%CATALINA_HOME%" -Djava.io.tmpdir="%CATALINA_TMPDIR%" %MAINCLASS% %CMD_LINE_ARGS% %ACTION%
goto end
:doSecurityJpda
%_EXECJAVA% %JAVA_OPTS% -Xms256m -Xmx384m %CATALINA_OPTS% -Xrunjdwp:transport=%JPDA_TRANSPORT%,address=%JPDA_ADDRESS%,server=y,suspend=n %DEBUG_OPTS% -Djava.endorsed.dirs="%JAVA_ENDORSED_DIRS%" -classpath "%CLASSPATH%" -Djava.security.manager -Djava.security.policy=="%SECURITY_POLICY_FILE%" -Dcatalina.base="%CATALINA_BASE%" -Dcatalina.home="%CATALINA_HOME%" -Djava.io.tmpdir="%CATALINA_TMPDIR%" %MAINCLASS% %CMD_LINE_ARGS% %ACTION%
goto end

:end

fields.description:
To reproduce this issue - follow these steps:

1. From the Home page - select "Configure your Dashboard".
2. Select "Add".
3. Select "Show Saved Filter" and click the "Add" button.
4. Select options fopr the filter and click "Save".
5. Select the Home page and note that the following error message is displayed in place of the portlet:

Error rendering /portlets/dashboard/savedfilter.jsp: /home/keithb/src/atlassian/jira/resin/work/_portlets/_dashboard/_savedfilter__jsp.java:0:0:0:0: Semantic Warning: The file "/usr/java/j2sdk1.4.2/jre/classes" is not a valid directory. /home/keithb/src/atlassian/jira/resin/work/_portlets/_dashboard/_savedfilter__jsp.java:0:0:0:0: Semantic Warning: The file "/usr/java/j2sdk1.4.2/jre/lib/i18n.jar" does not exist or else is not a valid zip file. /portlets/dashboard/savedfilter.jsp:6: Semantic Error: Ambiguous invocation of method "findValue". At least two methods are accessible from here: "java.lang.Object findValue(java.lang.String $1) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException;" declared in type "webwork.util.ValueStack" and "java.lang.Object findValue(webwork.util.Query $1) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException;" declared in type "webwork.util.ValueStack". .
Removing and recreating this portlet may solve the problem.
fields.summary: Show Saved Filter causes exception in rendering portlet.
Resolve workflow option available when issue is already resolved

fields.description: At the moment we have "Allow unassigned issues" checked in the preferences, and whilst this is useful, at present we are ending up with a large number of unassigned issues because the default behaviour of the Create Issue form is to not have an assignee. It would be nice to set a default assignee, and if "Allow unassigned issues" was selected then an issue creator would have to actively de-select the assignee to leave the issue in an unassigned state.
fields.summary: Deafult assignee event if allow unassigned issues is selected

fields.description:
Through circumstances not yet understood, it is possible to create a new JIRA issue with no status.  When such an issue is viewed, the status icon is blank, and in the log there is a long stack trace:

[ERROR] ServletValueStack - -METHOD: "string", exception:  <java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException>java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
    at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor6.invoke(Unknown Source)
    at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
...
...
...
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: [GenericEntity.get] "name" is not a field of Issue
    at org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericEntity.get(GenericEntity.java:150)
    at org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericEntity.getString(GenericEntity.java:343)
    ... 95 more


From examining the change history, such issues appear to belong in the 'Open' status.  Clicking 'Resolve' and then 'Reopen' fixes the issue.
fields.summary: Issues with no status, causing '"name" is not a field of Issue' exceptions

fields.description:
How can I translate the following workflow-actions?

* Resolve
* In progress
* Reopen
* Close
* ...
fields.summary: Are workflow-actions translatable?

fields.description:
Out organization has been creating and using custom fields. Custom fields are being used mainly to tag or flag issues for better filtering and extra-classification of issues. However, when listing the issues, it is desired to list issues with the custom fields as extra display column. In most cases, these custom field values are more informative than just filtering.

Please advise if this feature is already in 2.5. 2.3 does not seem to have it. Or if it will ever be part of any future versions.
fields.summary: Ability to select display columns when listing issues

fields.description: If you have a custom field of an enumerated type with a long list of possible selections, you really need that list in alphabetical order to help users find the option they wish to select.  Initially creating the options in alphabetical order manually is not that big of a deal b/c you can enter them in in aphabetical order, but maintaining it is a real hassle because for each new option you have to manually run it up the list to the correct spot.  With a web interface and a long list of options, this is very tedious takes alot of time.  It would be nice to be given an option on the administration screen to have the system automatically order the list of options in alphabetical order.
fields.summary: Allow custom field options to be sorted alphabetically

fields.description: In the "Add New Notification" view => a single user isn't taken by the user overview popup window.
fields.summary: Single User isn't taken in the Add New Notification view

fields.description:
Firstly I love the Road Map view.

I often find I wanna move stuff forwards or backwards in releases based on time. e.g. if I need to get a release out but have stuff not yet implemented, bump them back etc.

What would totally rock would be to allow easy moving of issues between 2 releases.

e.g. imagine current release and release + 1. Then have 2 columns with all the issues assigned for each release. Then allow multi-select and << or >> to easily shuffle things around.

Right now its quite a lot of navigation to move an issue to a diffferent release. (browse -> view -> edit -> change release -> browse). so it can be quite painful for lots of heavy shuffling.

A simple 'edit roadmap' to allow stuff to be moved would be awesome! :)
fields.summary: have easy roadmap editor to allow issues to be moved forwards & backwards in releases

fields.description: The Excel view does not contain the description column, even if this is added to the navigator view columns.  Many users expect the Excel view to reflect the Navigator view, especially now this is customisable.
fields.summary: Description does not appear in Excel view

fields.description: We should set up JIRA Standalone (Tomcat) to run inside a JVM sandbox, limiting JIRA's abilities to only those necessary.  This would prevent any uncontrolled dependencies on external websites (see JRA-2776), and prevent certain types of security breaches.
fields.summary: Run JIRA Standalone in a JVM sandbox
Can't create new issue when opensymphony.com is down

fields.description: Bulk change of "Affects Version" is not implemented.
fields.summary: Bulk Change of "Affects Version" is not implemented

fields.description:
I changed the date format from dd-MMM-yyyy to MM-dd-yyyy. Everything was fine.
I then deleted an obsolete issue type that we had created, "Project Management Project".
Immediately thereafter I lost the ability to edit or view date fields. After reverting to our backup of JIRA and reverting to default fields, I now receive the following error when logging a new issue.

"Form Errors: 
Exception: java.lang.NullPointerException"

I also get nullpointer errors when using the calendar applet to enter a date, or delete an issue. Any ideas on whay I can do to fix this?
fields.summary: Form Error when Creating or Deleting an issue

fields.description:
Bear with me - it makes sense!

I need to add custom fields to some projects - these fields are shared between projects in the same category.  Say I have ten categories of project, each using their own custom field layout.

In order to have a custom field shared by more than 1 project, I need to create a *global* field and then quickly hide it in the default (system) field layout before anyone notices.  This is not *so* bad, but then I have to go through every other field layout and hide the new field (before anyone notices), which is a bit of a git.

If you make the new field hidden by default, adding it becomes rather more manageable.
fields.summary: Make global custom fields hidden by default

fields.description: It would be really great to be able to do some filtering on the Work Log information.  E.g. view all resolved issues that have estimated time remaining > 0 (indicating people have not filled in the Work Log).
fields.summary: Allow filtering on work log information

fields.description: We have a requirement for a custom list field that is a required field.  However, we don't want to pre-empt a response by defaulting to any one of the possible items.  We want instead a blank line (or 'Please select' or something) at the top of the select box.  If we put 'Please select' or similar in the list, that becomes a valid option which is not what we want.
fields.summary: Allow 'No default' for custom select lists

fields.description:
I cannot edit the Fix Version for issues that have been created in Jira.  I can create an issue and set the Fix Version, that is fine.  However, when I go back in to edit the issue the Fix Version field says 'Unknown' - there is no drop-down.  If I save the issue, the Fix Version is lost.

This works just fine on the Standalone edition....
fields.summary: Cannot set Fix Version on edit issue screen

fields.description:
I created an issue then chose "Start Progress" from workflow.  It appeared in my "In Progress" box on the dashboard.  This is good.

Then I assigned it to someone else.  It stayed on my dashboard.  This is bad.

Then I assigned it back to myself, started progress, stopped it again, assigned it to someone else.  No longer in my dashboard.  This is good.


Which of these is not like the others?
fields.summary: Issue stays in my "In Progess" even after assigned away

fields.description:
In JIRA 2.5.2 (not 2.5.1 or 2.5), pressing alt-f does not have the effect of clicking the 'Find Issues' link as usual.  This is because there is a missing internationalization key.

To fix this in 2.5.2, edit atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/classes/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport.properties, locate the line 

alt.text.findissues = <u>F</u>IND ISSUES

and below it add:

alt.text.findissues.accessKey = f
fields.summary: Find Issues access key ('f') does not work

fields.description:
From a user email:

If you assign an in progress issue (initially assigned to yourself) to someone else, the issue continues to appear in finds
where the filter assignee=current user.  Flushing issue cache DOES NOT resolve problem. Steps to reproduce:

1. Create an issue, assign to yourself.
2. Start Progress on the issue.
3. Assign the issue to someone else.
4. Execute a find where the asignee=current user.  The issue still appears in the list - even though it is NOT assigned to
current user.
fields.summary: Reassigning in-progress issue doesn't update search indexes

fields.description:
The Idea is to have multiple dashboards which can be navigated with tabs at the top of the page.

There will be tabs at the top:
My Workspaces
Group/Shared Workspaces

and links on the right for:
Create Workspace
Edit Workspace
Delete Workspace


The implementation will be pretty much the same as it is now using portal pages.
The current default page will always be present in "My Workspaces" and called default.  (This will require and upgrade task).

All other pages will be created with the name the user specifies.
The Manager will need to change be able to retrieve all pages.

Entity Changes,
It maybe neccesary to change the table to allow ordering of pages as well as whether the page is shared or not (same as filters).  It may be a good idea to take this out into another table to allow multiple entities to be shared.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-2836].
  {panel}

Before issue field layout schemes, we had to create a custom field per project, even if the field was the same across many projects.  As a result, we now have a proliferation of 'Originator' custom fields for all projects that wanted this field.

Now with the great new IFLS I can create a global 'Originator' field and only show this to the projects that care.

So, I want to move all the data from the old per-project 'Originator' field into the new global 'Originator' field.

When I delete the per-project 'Originator' field then, I would like the option of moving the data into another field.

I bet this is one of those things that is easy to request and a git to implement, but it would be great.

Perhaps meanwhile a bit of Jelly-age might help...?

fields.description:
This is related to JRA-2814 in the sense that it is useful for large installations.

Currently for every project I create, I typically need to create one or more groups.  This might be the "developers" or maybe "release managers" or other such roles.

Once I establish these roles using groups, I unfortunately have to create a separate permission scheme that map to these specific group names.  This leads to a very large number of permission schemes, usually 1-to-1 with the # of projects.

Instead it would be nice to define some custom project-level attributes such as the "group that is the developers" or "group that are the administrators".  Then my permission scheme could just be the scheme that says the developers could do this and the release managers could do this and the testers could do this and the internationalization team can do this.

Right now "scheme" is a bit misleading for permissions because it's not really so much a "scheme" so much as a straight-forward ACL.  By allowing a project to have ad-hoc project-specific groups, my permission scheme can become a scheme in the policy sense, and the project then maps to groups which becomes the ACL.  Poorly worded, but hopefully you can see where I'm going.
fields.summary: Role based permission schemes (eg. 'grant BROWSE to ${project}-users')

fields.description:
When a user re-opens a bug that has been marked resolved, he or she should be able to change the fix-for version (assuming appropriate permissions).  This is important because the bug might be marked fix-for a version that has already been released.  In this case, it's too late to fix it for that version, and the re-opened bug might be missed in filters of bugs for upcoming releases.

(PS This just happened to me -- I didn't see the re-opened bug until too late.)
fields.summary: Ability to change Fix-for when re-opening a bug

fields.description:
Ref: http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/csv_import.html

We ought to import the CSV importer code into JIRA, and make it a separate page like the Bugzilla importer.  We could then remove the need for users to discover the project id.  The import JSP and example needs some general cleaning up.

The chief impediment to this seems to be finding a CSV library that handled Excel's format.  We currently use ostermillerutils_1_02_21.jar which is GPL, so we can't redistribute it.
fields.summary: Create CSV importer page

fields.description:
Our JBoss docs are wrong.  They list:

    <datasource name="defaultDS"
      helper-class="org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericHelperDAO"
      field-type-name="mysql" check-on-start="true"
      add-missing-on-start="true">
      <jndi-jdbc jndi-server-name="default" jndi-name="java:/MysqlDS" />
    </datasource>

There are a couple of extra attributes in later versions of JIRA.  It should be:

    <datasource name="defaultDS" field-type-name="mysql"
      helper-class="org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericHelperDAO"
      check-on-start="true" use-foreign-keys="false"
      use-foreign-key-indices="false"
      check-fks-on-start="false"
      check-fk-indices-on-start="false"
      add-missing-on-start="true">
        <jndi-jdbc jndi-server-name="default" jndi-name="java:MysqlDS"/>
    </datasource>
fields.summary: JBoss documentation wrong - missing datasource attributes

fields.description:
I tried to migrate from version 2.5.1 to 2.5.2 and kept the database-instance the same.

In version 2.5.1 opening an issue is an action where waiting is maybe 1 sec.
Since version 2.5.2 opening an issue is waiting more then 15 secs.

It's also impossible to do workflow-actions (closing, in progress, resolving, reopening,...)

The JIRA/Tomcat Windows says that there is a time-out with your workflow-engine findin a host.

When i copy following two files back from version 2.5.2 to version 2.5.1 (server.xml and entityengine.xml) version 2.5.1 works just fine.
fields.summary: Opening issue is very slow and workflow-actions aren't available

fields.description:
I was evaluating version 2.5.1 for our company CIPAL in Belgium when version 2.5.2 was released.

Because for us it was important to know how easy it was to upgrade JIRA with another language (we are translating the frontend into Dutch) we tried to upgrade from 2.5.1 to 2.5.2.

At first it seemed to be OK until we wanted to create an issue. There was a message indicating there was a problem with the workflow. So we can't create issues anymore.

At first I though I made a fault so i tried a clean install from your version 2.5.2 on a new MySQL-database. After entering a project and versions the fault-message didn't dissapear.

In attach you can find some screenshots.
fields.summary: Unable to create issue

There should be a way (for an administrator only?) to change the reporter of a bug.  Sometimes someone sitting at someone else's computer  files a bug and it gets filed with the wrong reporter.  Then the wrong person gets email about it, etc.

Also, I want to delete a user who is no longer with our company.  But since he filed some bugs, JIRA won't let me remove him.  And I can't change the reporter, or even change it to <unknown> or something.
fields.summary: Changing the Reporter of a bug

fields.description:
We have a german locale (browser and server) but a JIRA installation which is set to UK English.

To schedule an issue to december, the date picker returns a "12 dec 2003". JIRA complains about this date (error).
If we use a german-style "12 dez 2003", it works fine. This is very misleading, as one would expect UK month names in an UK locale.

In general, the localization of the date picker seems incomplete.
(when I set the default locale of JIRA to german, I still get a "12 dec 2003")

Cheers, 
 Ingomar

fields.description:
On jira-user, we discussed the idea of introducing filters to reduce the size of the content sent to clients. A user mentionned that when he found out that returning more than 500 issues in a search produced a lot of unneeded contents. 

The thread can be found here:
http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?forumID=46&threadID=4224&messageID=130127458#130127458

Adding filtering to both compress and strip characters out might help.
Compress filters are implemented in Tomcat examples. A simple filter for stripping unneeded HTML characters from the web

Mike came in and specified the needs as: 

"I believe what you need to do (to get maximum return for minimum effort) iscontract 'any number of space characters down to one' (ie '   \n    ' to '') to ensure that the space always remains (blocks of whitespace are treatedthe same no matter how long they are IIRC). I haven't seen any servlet filters that do this magically though surprisingly enough, shouldn¹t be _too_ hard to write - although in somecases I think the computation cost of parsing all that HTML and stripping itwould be more than the time to send the page so not worth it? It would needto have some size factors built in."

I am willing to work on it (I have a mostly working prototype) if someone gives me a couple of days to go back to it.

Note: it is very important to check a log the stripping as browsers are very sensitive to page contents. It should also probably be easily disabled, at least for testing purposes.
fields.summary: Reduce size of HTML sent to browsers

fields.description:
After installing JIRA 2.5.2 I added an issue and got an ConnectionException + InternalWorkflowException.

[FATAL] XMLWorkflowFactory - -Error creating workflow descriptor
<java.net.ConnectException: Connection timed out: connect>
2003-11-26 17:24:58,331 ERROR [web.action.issue.CreateIssueDetails]
com.opensymphony.workflow.InternalWorkflowException
java.net.SocketException: Connection reset by peer: socket write error
        at java.net.SocketOutputStream.socketWrite0(Native Method)
....

The reason is that our bugtrack server is behind a firewall and could not connect to zeus.atlassian.com to download
the /osworkflow/workflow_2_5.dtd file (which obviously is needed).

This is not documented, and i can't find an option to let JIRA go over our proxy. I had to open our firewall for zeus.atlassian.com.

This should be at least stated in the requirements for JIRA, the file should be shipped with the standard install, or an better errormessage should be generated, because it prevents adding new issues and leaves one pretty puzzled.
fields.summary: InternalWorkflowException when adding issue - JIRA trying to download remote osworkflow DTD

fields.description:
From a jira-user post:

>When I try to reindex our issue database, I am getting this error:
>
>Exception reindexing: com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.IndexException:
>Error closing writer: java.io.FileNotFoundException:
>C:\test\jira\indexes\issues\_32.fnm (Too many open files):
>
>I wrote a small java program to find out how many files can be open before
>this error is thrown, and the number is 2036.  Trying to open #2037 causes
>the exception.
>
>Does anyone know how to get around this limit in Windows XP?  Is there a
>setting somewhere?
>
>Are there some properties or settings somewhere in Jira for Lucene that I
>can play around with to try to get the indexing to succeed?
>
>(I'm using jira 2.5.1, tomcat 4.1, remote database)


To which Hani replies:

If you have source, one way of fixing this is by ensuring that you're
using the latest lucene RC and enabling compound files by calling
writer.setUseCompoundFile(true); whenever jira creates a lucene writer.
This drastically reduces the number of files it opens and so avoids the
issue below. I'd suggest the jira guys try to make this change in the
next release (assuming of course it passes the rigorous QA procedures ;))
fields.summary: Reindexing fails: IndexException: Too many open files
